title: What element was discovered first? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hydrogen was the first element Nebulae formed from hydrogen.* Nebulae evolve, a spiral like our galaxy is typical. First generation stars formed, different sizes, some average, some of very large mass. The bigger the star the brighter and faster it burns, medium and smaller ones have a longer life When first generation stars collapsed and went supernova, other elements were formed. Second generation stars incorporate newer elements, and big ones going supernova generate even more complex materials. *The initial hydrogen is produced from space energies. Chemical elements identified in our sun Chemical elements identified in our sun Some biggie presentations there, do not miss, BBC et cetera, at least three in detail to do for sure, but real student ought to double that, at least. In my case I am saying nothing about a ‘big bang’ because I see no evidence for that, plus there is the constant precipitation of hydrogen from primordial little known space energies. The stars have to evolve a good while prior to suitable planets for life, this allows for a decent abundance of elements. There is tremendous violence earlier on too, things have to settle down a good bit prior to even higher beings there, let alone evolving beings. Our sun is average as to mass, a second generation (or later) star. One million miles diameter is average, so our Sun is smaller, I guess 1.2 million miles diameter still average. I am not an expert on this. How Big is the Sun? | Size of the Sun Evolution of nebulae in detail is in this book*** of about 2,097 pages. a sharp English language person can get a fair grasp of first half in six months, provided not delayed by trying to absorb total understanding about God prematurely in the beginning papers about Trinity. Look at Table of Contents on left, do the SCIENCE related papers, but the Presenters are High Angels and such, not professors nor humans, nor ETs. *** Paper 57 - The Origin of Urantia (Angel’s name for our planet) Much of the book is about science subjects, stellar evolution, types of nebulae, origin of matter, energies known and little known, and so forth. Paper 32 - The Evolution of Local Universes Paper 41 - Physical Aspects of the Local Universe Paper 42 - Energy- Mind and Matter *** important as to this question Paper 106 - Universe Levels of Reality Titles of the Papers Titles of the Papers author of each is shown by name All put together, if done = a very good detailed synopsis, more so if you do not neglect the second reference ! There are several long and detailed science papers… Infinity Explained Infinity. This level is pre-existential and postexperiential. Unqualified unity of infinity is a hypothetical reality before all beginnings and after all destinies.

There are many material can be found in the environment in elemental form. Humans first element was most probably the carbon, in form of charcoal. Other natural elements are sulfur, gold, silver, chopper.As definition, ancient greeks created the definition of elements, but they called something very different thing under these word. (earth, air, fire, water).Chemical definition: "In 1661, Robert Boyle proposed his theory of corpuscularism which favoured the analysis of  matter as constituted by irreducible units of matter (atoms) and,  choosing to side with neither Aristotle's view of the four elements nor  Paracelsus' view of three fundamental elements, left open the question  of the number of elements.The first modern list of chemical elements was given in Antoine Lavoisier's 1789 Elements of Chemistry, which contained thirty-three elements, including light and caloric. By 1818, Jöns Jakob Berzelius had determined atomic weights for forty-five of the forty-nine then-accepted elements. Dmitri Mendeleev had sixty-six elements in his periodic table of 1869."

A necessary prerequisite to the construction of the periodic table was the discovery of the individual elements. Although elements such as Gold, Silver, Tin, Cooper, Lead and Mercury have been known since Antiquity, the First Scientific Discovery of an Element occurred in 1649 when Hennig Brand discovered Phosphorous. Phosphorus was first discovered in the late 1600s by Hennig Brand, who was conducting Experiments with Urine and collected Phosphorous from condensation. He thought he had discovered the Philosopher's stone, an item that would turn any metal into gold and decided to keep it a secret.

If you are referring to unrecorded history then Copper was probably the first metal mined and crafted by humans .It was originally obtained as a native metal (a metal found in nature in its metallic form) and later from the smelting of ores. Earliest estimates of the discovery of copper suggest around 9000 BCE in the Middle East. If you are referring to recorded history then Phosphorous was the first element to be discovered. It was fist chemically prepared from urine in an accidental discovery in 1669 by German Alchemist Hennig Brand, making him the first person in history to have discovered an element. Brand’s urine reduction recipe can be found at Hennig Brand - Wikipedia (definitely don’t try this at home!)

It’s difficult to say that the earliest known elements were “discovered” because humans have had knowledge of copper, gold, iron, tin, lead, silver for a long time. The first element to be predicted in modern times was phosporous (derived from urine). After that cobalt, platinum, nickel, magnesium, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, barium, and chlorine. In terms of actually isolating the element and getting a pure sample, the order is oxygen, phosphorous, cobalt, nickel, nitrogen, chlorine, manganese, molybdenum, tungsten and chromium.

Chemical element - Wikipedia Ten materials familiar to various prehistoric cultures are now known to be chemical elements: Carbon, copper, gold, iron, lead, mercury, silver, sulfur, tin, and zinc. Carbon - Wikipedia Carbon was discovered in prehistory and was known in the forms of soot and charcoal to the earliest human civilizations. Charcoal burner - Wikipedia Even in ancient times, charcoal was manufactured in kilns. Logs were arranged in a conical heap (a charcoal kiln or pile) around posts, a fire shaft was made using brushwood and wood chips and covered with an airtight layer of grass, moss, and earth. What element was discovered first? My guess would be carbon.

This answer may bring a smile on your face, but, please bear it and enjoy it. This question would have been best answered by OUR Ancestors (Yes, my and your ancestors) living in Africa millions of years ago. During heavy thunderstorms they observed repeatedly over thousands of years that different trees caught fire from lightning strikes. What was left was something black and amorphous. Later they learnt to light fires and found similar black residue from the burnt wood. They started using the black residue for marking and other uses. This black residue was given many names in the local basic sound language- with time region.

Hydrogen was the first element What is element with example? You could build living things from o handful of elements based on carbon, and you could make the water that covers most of our planet from just two elements - hydrogen and oxygen. But to make everything on Earth you would need about 100 elements in total. Most element occur naturally- they are locked in rocks for drifting around in the atmosphere. But since elements are made from protons,neutrons and electrons glued together by strong forces, it's also possible to build brand new ones. Scientist have done just this in laboratories, pushing the total number of known elements to 118.[1] Footnotes[1] What is element with example?

A necessary prerequisite to the construction of the periodic table was the discovery of the individual elements. Although elements such as gold,silver, tin, copper, lead and mercury have been known since antiquity, the first scientific discovery of an element occurred in 1649 when Hennig Brand discovered phosphorous.

There was only Hydrogen... Which forms Stars... Stars make Helium, Helium makes Lithium, which then makes Beryllium then Baron, Carbon... etc.. then Stars explode and form more elements... then planets are created and form more elements. But also know that some elements are man made. Space is filled with Anti-matter (Dark matter / Dark energy) and hydrogen and its still is the most abundant elements in the universe.

Arsenic is an element in the Earth's crust that occurs naturally. It is usually with a variety of other elements including oxygen, sulfur and chlorine to form an inorganic compound. People may be exposed to arsenic if they work at hazardous waste sites. Exposure to high levels of this element can eventually cause death, and repeated exposure to low levels of arsenic can cause a discoloration on the skin and even the appearance of warts or corns.

From https://www.wou.edu/las/physci/ch412/perhist.htm QUOTE Although elements such as gold, silver, tin, copper, lead and mercury have been known since antiquity, the first scientific discovery of an element occurred in 1649 when Hennig Brand discovered phosphorous. UNQUOTE

Hmm…… Q. What was the first element created? A. Technetium, Tc, #43, was the first artificially produced element. It was isolated by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segrè in 1937. Technetium was created by bombarding molybdenum atoms with deuterons that had been accelerated by a device called a cyclotron.
Different views regarding the first element discovered can be encountered. It appears that the first element discovered was phosphorus.
thats a good question. the first element that was discovered was phosphorus. hennig brand was the discoverer of phosphorus.
As per google, the first scientific discovery of an element occurred in 1649 when Hennig Brand discovered phosphorous.
The first discovered element is copper (9000 BCE). The people obtained copper as native metal.  For more info read this Timeline of chemical element discoveries
